articles.title: Spain Advances to Davis Cup Final Against Italy After Tough Win
articles.summary: Spain has secured a spot in the Davis Cup final by defeating Germany in a thrilling match that went down to a deciding doubles encounter. The victory was highlighted by Pablo Carreno Busta's win in the opening singles against Jan-Lennard Struff, giving Spain an early advantage. However, Germany's Alexander Zverev, ranked third in the world, fought back to defeat Jaume Munar, leveling the tie and forcing a doubles decider. In the crucial doubles match, Marcel Granollers and Pedro Martinez, who had previously helped Spain in the quarter-finals, delivered a strong performance to beat Kevin Krawietz and Tim Puetz in three sets. This marks Spain's first final appearance since 2019, as they aim for their seventh Davis Cup title. The absence of injured world number one Carlos Alcaraz adds challenge, but the team remains motivated. They will face Italy, the two-time defending champions, in the final in Bologna. Italy, missing top players like Jannik Sinner and Lorenzo Musetti, earned their place by beating Belgium. This final is significant as it is the first Davis Cup meeting between Spain and Italy in 19 years, with team captains David Ferrer and Filippo Volandri having played in their last encounter in 2006. Ferrer expressed pride in his team's effort and excitement for the upcoming match, emphasizing the need to rest and prepare for a competitive final against Italy's skilled squad.

articles.title: The Life and Legacy of Fashion Designer Paul Costelloe
articles.summary: Paul Costelloe, a prominent Irish fashion designer, passed away at the age of 80 in London following a brief illness, as announced by his family. Born in Dublin, he studied at the Grafton Academy of Fashion Design and furthered his education in Paris at the Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture. In 1979, he established his own label, Paul Costelloe Collections, and showcased his work at major fashion weeks in London, Paris, Milan, and New York. A significant aspect of his career was his role as the personal designer to Diana, Princess of Wales, from 1983 until her death in 1997. Costelloe was known for incorporating traditional Irish fabrics such as linen and tweed into his designs, and he collaborated with retailers like Dunnes Stores. He faced criticism in 1998 for comments about Irish women's style but later noted Ireland's evolution in fashion. The Taoiseach, Micheál Martin, expressed sadness and recognized Costelloe as an icon who brought Irish fashion to the global stage, highlighting his enduring influence on the industry.

articles.title: Media Merger: Daily Mail Buys Telegraph
articles.summary: The Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT) has agreed to purchase the Daily and Sunday Telegraph for £500 million, marking a significant shift in the UK media landscape. This deal follows the collapse of a previous bid by RedBird IMI, a joint venture involving the UAE and US private equity. Approval from Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy is required under public interest and foreign influence regulations. The Telegraph has faced uncertainty for over two years since RedBird IMI paid off its debts, aiming for ownership. Dame Caroline Dineage, chair of the Culture, Media and Sport Committee, emphasized the need for resolution to support the business and staff, while respecting the government's quasi-judicial role. DMGT's chairman, Lord Rothermere, expressed admiration for the Telegraph, pledging editorial independence and investment to enhance its global presence. The acquisition would integrate the Telegraph into DMGT's portfolio, including titles like the i Paper and Metro, with assurances of compliance to UK laws and no foreign state involvement.

articles.title: Radiohead's Return: A Hit-Packed London Concert
articles.summary: Radiohead delivered a captivating performance at London's O2 Arena, marking their first UK gig in 99 months and a decade since their last new music release. The band, led by Thom Yorke, showcased songs spanning their entire career, from early hits like The Bends to recent works such as A Moon Shaped Pool. Despite some minor timing and tuning issues, possibly due to rustiness from the long hiatus, the concert was largely spell-binding. Highlights included energetic tracks like 2+2=5, which resonated with current political themes, and experimental pieces that featured extended musical sections. The rhythm section, enhanced by session musician Chris Vatalaro, stood out with danceable grooves in songs like National Anthem and Idioteque. While the audience struggled to clap along to complex rhythms in 15 Step, they showed unified appreciation through head-bobbing. Crowd-pleasers like Lucky and No Surprises provided emotional depth, making the event a triumphant return for the band and a memorable experience for fans who had eagerly anticipated it.

articles.title: Cobolli's Historic Tie-Break Victory Propels Italy to Davis Cup Final
articles.summary: In a thrilling Davis Cup semifinal, Italian tennis player Flavio Cobolli secured a dramatic victory over Belgium's Zizou Bergs by winning a 32-point tie-break, saving seven match points in the process. The match, held in Bologna, lasted over three hours and ended with Cobolli winning 6-3, 6-7 (5-7), 7-6 (17-15), sparking wild celebrations among the home crowd. This tie-break is the sixth-longest in Davis Cup history, highlighting the intensity of the contest. Cobolli expressed that achieving this win was one of the best moments of his life, emphasizing the emotional effort he put in for his team, family, and country. Italy's captain, Filippo Volandri, praised Cobolli's performance, noting that it was 95% heart and only 5% tactics, and highlighted the team's strong bench support, including Matteo Berrettini who won his match earlier. With this win, Italy advances to the final against Spain or Germany, aiming to become the first nation in 53 years to win three consecutive Davis Cup titles, despite missing top players like Jannik Sinner and Lorenzo Musetti.

articles.title: Eurovision Implements Rule Changes Following Voting Disputes
articles.summary: The Eurovision Song Contest is updating its regulations in response to controversies surrounding Israel's performance in the recent competition. Israel secured the highest number of public votes in May, placing second overall after jury scores were factored in, which prompted concerns from several nations. Key changes include reducing the number of votes per fan from 20 to 10 and reinstating juries for the semi-finals. Additionally, a new ban prohibits contestants and broadcasters from engaging in promotional campaigns by third parties, such as governments, after reports emerged that an Israeli agency used state resources to encourage voting for its entry. Martin Green, the Eurovision director, cited extensive feedback from members and fans, emphasizing the need to review rules to prevent undue influence. He noted fears that third-party promotions, especially by governments, were disproportionate and undermined the contest's spirit. The issue is compounded by opposition to Israel's participation due to the Gaza conflict, with countries like Spain and Ireland threatening boycotts. Green hopes these measures will reassure participants of Eurovision's impartiality and neutrality, stressing that the contest should focus on music and unity, not geopolitics. A planned vote on Israel's involvement was cancelled in November and may be discussed later, reflecting ongoing tensions.
